title: 'Autumn bounce' in house prices missing as sellers hold back
text:
A seasonal bounce in Britain's house prices failed to materialise, as "thousands of potential sellers" held off putting their homes on the market, Rightmove said.

The average price for homes going up for sale rose by just 0.6pc in October, in what was the slowest rate for the month since the financial crisis. Over the last 10 years, prices have risen by 1.6pc on average between September and October, known as the "autumn bounce".

On a year-on-year basis, asking prices were down 0.2pc across the UK, although the falls were larger in Greater London and the East of England at 1.1pc and 0.7pc respectively.

The property site said this came as the "imminence of the Brexit deadline" was causing sellers...
description: A seasonal bounce in Britain's house prices failed to materialise, as "thousands of potential sellers" held off putting their homes on the market, Rightmove said.
